description.narrative: Culture Fund of ZimbabweTrust (CFoZT) has applied for SEK6 million funding to implement an arts and culture intervention focussing on freedom of expression, human rights and gender equality.The Project will seek to address the sometimes difficult to handle subjects of human rights, freedom of expression and gender equality through use of arts and culture. The project will, broadly, seek to transform mindsets around these development issues so that they are part of the culture; assertion of and recognition of human rights, gender equality and freedom of expression become the new normal. The project will engage arts and culture agents through an open call for proposals and engage as subgrantees to implement the project. The proposed intervention reinforces over 10 years Swedish Government support to the arts and culture sector in Zimbabwe. While previous tended to support arts and culture in and for itself the latest proposal focuses on using the sector as a conduit for pertinent development objectives like human rights and freedom of expression. Complementary to this thrust there is also a stronger emphasis on Results Based Management (RBM) as an approach. In order to test the efficacy of this new approach and leave room for alignment with new Development Country Strategy, the Embassy of Sweden requested Culture Fund to submit a proposal for 1 year only. There is scope for ramping up this intervention once the new approach is tested and proven, and the partners given time to adapt.

Culture Fund of ZimbabweTrust (CFoZT) has applied for SEK6 million funding to implement an arts and culture intervention focussing on freedom of expression, human rights and gender equality.The Project will seek to address the sometimes difficult to handle subjects of human rights, freedom of expression and gender equality through use of arts and culture. The project will, broadly, seek to transform mindsets around these development issues so that they are part of the culture; assertion of and recognition of human rights, gender equality and freedom of expression become the new normal. The project will engage arts and culture agents through an open call for proposals and engage as subgrantees to implement the project. The proposed intervention reinforces over 10 years Swedish Government support to the arts and culture sector in Zimbabwe. While previous tended to support arts and culture in and for itself the latest proposal focuses on using the sector as a conduit for pertinent development objectives like human rights and freedom of expression. Complementary to this thrust there is also a stronger emphasis on Results Based Management (RBM) as an approach. In order to test the efficacy of this new approach and leave room for alignment with the anticipated new development Country Strategy, the Embassy of Sweden requested Culture Fund to submit a proposal for 1 year only. There is scope for ramping up this intervention once the new approach is tested and proven, and the partners given time to adapt.

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Culture Fund in its Culture Impacts programme embraced the rights based approach to programming. Cognizant of the centrality of the rights based approach to sustainable development Culture Fund worked in interlinked pathways of expression and gender with a rights framework overarching the entire intervention. There is a clear rights trajectory using the non-confrontational artistic products to address a diverse range of contentious rights issues. The Creative Arts facilitated dialogue on pertinent issues. However more can be done to ensure vibrant social actions beyond the dialogue to motivate collective social actions. Culture Impacts was implemented through three pathways, Free Expression, Gender Equality and Rights and Freedoms. The supported entities were firmly anchored in the creative sector and deployed creative tools to address the various pertinent development challenges.
The intervention ran rights awareness campaigns which exposed more than 60 000 people to the full range of fundamental rights which underpin free expression and democratic societies. This aspect exploited the power of the Creative Arts to deal with potentially contentious issues such as human rights. - The creative platforms offered alternative channels for people to debate, interrogate and ask important questions on topical and current issues. The robust post performance discussions were important tools for public engagement on development and informed public opinion.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
